title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: USDA reorganization will cut agricultural and forest research
items.description: One of the agency’s largest and most storied research facilities will be closed along with most forest research stations

items.title: ‘Things keep evolving into anteaters.’ Odd animals arose at least 12 separate times
items.description: Findings speak to the dramatic impact ants and termites can have on mammalian evolution

items.title: Congressional panels resist White House proposals for sharp cuts in indirect cost rates
items.description: Three spending panels say a 15% cap isn’t the right answer to nagging concerns about how universities are reimbursed

items.title: Columbia’s $221 million deal with Trump officials draws mixed reactions from researchers
items.description: Relief that NIH funding will be restored mingles with fears that academic independence will suffer—and that other universities will make similar concessions

items.title: This trilobite fossil became ancient Roman bling
items.description: It’s the first example of this common fossil found in the ancient Roman world

items.title: Fifteen years later, <cite>Science</cite> retracts ‘arsenic life’ paper despite study authors’ protests
items.description: Belated decision on widely disputed 2010 study pleases some critics but puzzles and dismays others

items.title: Three ancient human relatives once shared the same valley. Did they meet—and compete?
items.description: The world’s greatest concentration of ancestral human remains, in South Africa, poses a 2-million-year-old riddle of coexistence

items.title: Trump’s plan to slash global health spending rejected by key spending panel
items.description: House of Representatives committee signals support for HIV/AIDS and other funding

items.title: Cheap drug could fight malaria by spoiling mosquitoes’ blood meal
items.description: Field study in Kenya suggests innovative strategy has promise—but some researchers question its viability

items.title: Songbirds play optical tricks to make their feather colors ‘pop’
items.description: Concealed black or white bands on feathers boost the vibrancy of bird plumage
